I've always had wonderful dining experiences at Liliana's. During a recent brunch visit, I thoroughly enjoyed my shrimp and grits. I thought the shrimp were perfectly spiced and grilled. I appreciated they were fully shelled so I didn't have to create a mess with that. The gravy that's on the grits is truly amazing and I generally do not care for gravy.

Service was excellent during our recent Sunday visit, which is similar to our past experiences.

There was a man playing guitar, which made the experience that much nicer. The music was not too loud and complimented the atmosphere.

During other visits I have also enjoyed their extensive wine list. They do a great job with that.

I recommend a visit to Liliana's for dinner or brunch. The decor, service, food and music make it a unique dining experience.

Restaurant week.

Went here for an early Valentine's Day dinner and restaurant week special. Being gluten-free, I was dreading restaurant week--it's something we used to celebrate all the time, but I expected that this time we'd be out of luck because the odds of having a GF set menu are low. Because I apparently like making myself sad, I browsed all the menus, and discovered that Liliana's not only had GF options for their restaurant week selection, but MULTIPLE GF options. I was sold.

We made an online reservation which went well. Service was very attentive and pleasant, and we tried some great new wines. The food was fast and absolutely divine--I had a wild mushroom risotto that was to die for, and we enjoyed the desserts as well. (Added bonus: GF dessert options BEYOND flourless chocolate cake!)

We loved the ambiance and were very impressed overall. We'll definitely go again, especially since their normal menu has a vast array of GF options and awesome food.

I finally got to check this place out last Sunday, and  was disappointed.

My friends and I arrived around 2 pm, and sadly had to order from the brunch menu. My two companions ordered the Shrimp & Grits, and they both loved it. I ordered a standard breakfast plate with cheesy grits, bacon, potatoes and scrambled eggs. I found the bacon overcooked, the potatoes under-seasoned, the eggs too salty and the cheesy grits not cheesy enough. Everything on the plate was perfectly edible, but just not good enough to justify the $9 bill. The portions were also quite small.

We enjoyed sitting outside on the patio, and our server was nice and attentive.

I'll probably stop back again to try one of their lunch or dinner options.

The quality of everything I ordered here was awesome! 

My group had the calamari, corn bread, I ate Jambalaya and we all split a bananas foster for dessert. Everything was quite delicious, far exceeding my expectations. 

I would definitely recommend eating here.

We had been to Liliana's few times before and had good experience. This time it was different..
We were there on a Monday evening. There was another table inside, and few outside. Long story short.. we waited and waited at our table and did not get any service. I even talked to the person who seated us, but no one came. No waiter... no water. A waitstaff walked past our table to take care of the other table, others were cleaning the tables and talking,  but noone came to us. I am not a person who seeks high service, but this was just dishonoring. So we let the staff and host know that we were leaving... and went somewhere else. It ruined our evening. 

I really liked our previous experiences there. Probably bad day for us to be there? I lived in Louisiana for number of years, and was glad to find this place in Madison. We will be back some other time, and hope to get some Jambalaya served. :)
Everytime we come in, Chef Dave and his staff, and sometimes Lily are there welcoming you to experience their hospitality, vittles and ambiance.  Great food!!

very fresh ingredients , nice presentation wonderful flavors. I was expecting something heavier and I was very surprised. vegetarian options were nice to have I sat outside really nice and relaxing place gorgeous wine bar. 
I really loved the salad so fresh and yummy. it's hard to find good salads in Madison.

First time here.  The best food I had at a restaurant in a long time.  Everything was incredible and you could not ask for better service.  Our server Elaine was Awesome!!! Truly a hidden gem in the Madison area.

I think I may have a new favorite restaurant. Liliana's was very nice and I will definitely go back again soon.

Like Andy P. - we went on a Friday night without reservations. We waited about 45 minutes, but it didn't seem long at all. The decor is excellent and probably a bit nicer than we expected. Very impressive and good service. 

We also started with the Jalapeno Cranberry hush puppies - they were very good - but I expected a bit more Cranberry or Jalapeno flavor from them. Good none the less, but maybe a bit much for two people. (better for 4 or 5 I think). We ordered the Jambalaya and the Scallops for dinner. Both were cooked very well and were excellent. Probably the best Jambalaya I have had in a while. Only complaint was it could have had a touch more heat - I guess I like it pretty spicy.

Cost was pretty decent for what we ate and overall it was a great experience and a great value. They look to have a lot of special menu events and 'tastes' as well. Definitely a place I will return to again soon!

This is my second time here and I have to say the food here is awesome and fulfilling! Our service however, was only okay as our waitress wasn't as attentive as we would've liked. 

We ordered oysters as an appetizer and I will have to say we could've gone for another order! The sauce that came along with it was perfect!  I had the mushroom risotto with chicken and it was jam packed with creamy goodness! My sister had the jambalaya and my brother-in-law had the e'toffee. Both equally delicious. They have a "ghost pepper" sauce that my bro-in-law added into his dish as well. If you like spicy....I dare you to add the sauce!

We tried to call to order a simple lunch order to go for a lunch special for $10. We were rudely told they don't have it since forever by a "lady" , today on 02/16/15 around noon. We've ordered that special every other day few months back, so it was obvious they don't care about keeping loyal customers. Oh well. Thank you for showing your true service level.

Chef Dave's catering services at our wedding thoroughly disappointed us, and we have emailed, called, and met with him to convince him to accept responsibility in the role he had in making the meal a failure. He has sent us a small fraction of the refund we've requested and has been defensive in pointing fingers toward reasons why there were people who were not fed at our wedding. We concede that there are three things that we could have done to help him cater the wedding better: first, he requested pictures of the commercial kitchen which we never supplied (even though he never affirmatively expressed that he planned to use the commercial kitchen); two, we did not have a wedding planner; and three, a handful of our guests were the cause of miscommunication and chaos in the kitchen about how to carry out the dinner. To this day we're not sure what kind of preparation, ingredients, and care went into the food that was served on the day of our wedding, but throughout the process we didn't see evidence that anyone from Liliana's wanted to make our event a success. Chef Dave and Liliana's staff made a number of mistakes that were out of our control and beyond the scope of the effect of our mistakes that make us feel we deserve a refund: the invoice was four months late; the invoice was almost twice as much as our expressed budget; we worked with three different event managers; the event manager requested that we have four 8-foot tables which made the buffets look sparse; staff did not know how to pour beer and served drinks 3/4-way full; the chef forgot something in the parking lot and heated pasta in a large saucepan; the events manager did not use time wisely; staff had worked another event earlier in the day (even though Chef Dave said they only did one event per day); the MAC and cheese portions were half what they should have been; and as a there was leftover, uncooked food that wasn't made available to guests, among others. So there's a number of factors, mostly beyond our control, that caused the dinner to fail. We filed a complaint a month ago with the Better Business Bureau and he didn't respond.

I always have a pleasant experience here. We typically come early and eat in the bar area. The waiter we had was incredibly friendly and attentive. We ordered the cheese curds, shrimp po boys, and beignets. The cheese curds were light and delicious, the blackened shrimp in the po boy was cooked just right, and the beignets were hot and covered in a mountain of powdered sugar (as they should be.)

Highly recommend!

Take one of Chef Dave's cooking classes!!

Chef Dave has to be one of the nicest and most outgoing chefs/business owners in Madison. He goes ABOVE AND BEYOND in his cooking classes. For 4 hours I was learning, entertained and amused by his stories, knowledge and cooking tips. It was SO FUN!

Not only is he a great chef, but while were in class he told us how he HANDMADE each and every table, bar-top and did all the tile work on the floor himself when opening the restaurant. How awesome is that?? He also talked a lot about the farm-to-table food that he offers and how important it is to him to sustain relationships with local businesses and farmers which I appreciate. He really wants only the best for his food and customers, which definitely shows.

The food is so great at this restaurant. I have been for brunch as well as a private party that I threw at this location. Everything was flawless and my guests were impressed with the food and service that we were given.

Love this restaurant. Close to home, and has a great New Orleans feel. We chose this restaurant to tell my in-laws I was pregnant. Will always be a memorable place! I really liked the alligator appetizer and the drinks. The e'toufee was delicious, could be spicier.

I ordered the creole trio, my father a noodle dish with chicken, andouille, shrimp and vegetables, and my mother a noodle dish with a smoked pork shoulder. All the food was great and had generous portions of meat/ingredients (even the noodle dishes). I've been to New Orleans quite a bit (used to live in Texas so it was only a 5 hour drive) and this place brought back lots of good memories.

Their cornbread/biscuits are also quite good and there doesn't seem to be much of a need to order an appetizer making it a fairly reasonably priced place.

It's great this place has vegan and vegetarian options. We went there for brunch as a group of 17 people though and they assigned only one server to our table to do everything. We had a reservation so this was just poor staffing on their part. Our server did her very best but you can imagine she was super stressed and could not keep on top of everything. They refused to let us move inside even though it was quite chilly. I used to work in restaurants and you need at least two people for a table that size.

This is, by far, one of my favorite restaurants in the Madison area. I love being able to run into the owner's family when we go there and it's just some of the best service and some of the best Cajun style food outside of New Orleans.

I was completely underwhelmed by this establishment. First, let me say the service is superb. Absolutely friendly, attentive, wonderful. 

The menu seems large but it just does not seem to have very may options. I ordered the chicken salad sandwich with a cup of soup and a white bean salad. The salad lacked any flavor whatsoever. It was served cold and just felt like slimy little beads in my mouth.

The sandwich was good. It was a twist on a traditional chicken salad. The bread was hearty, yet you could bite into it easily. Nothing great. The soup was ok but it had (possibly a cream or yogurt swirl) served over the top. Just not really for me.

I doubt I would go back.

Absolutely wonderful.  I went there with my parents and we had a superb time.  We showed up on a Friday night without a reservation and had to wait about 45 min, but they got a bar to do that in.  

The dining room is very elegant for a Cajun place.  I had the jambalaya and it was a "wet" variety of jambalaya.  The andouille was particularly smokey and delicious.  Loved every bite.  My mother had the crawfish etouffee, and my father had the bouillabaisse.  We all enjoyed our selections very much.  We also got a hushpuppy appetizer which was good, but probably unnecessary.

I have no problem giving the place all five stars.  The food took a while to reach us but when it did... yum.

Had the Wisconsin board, which was slightly different than expected (fried corn beef type patty instead of charcuterie, but then received more cheese than expected!). We also tried the Liliana's pasta, jambalaya, and seafood gumbo which were large portions, slightly salty but with lots of sausage! Service was a little slow in getting water refills, etc but overall enjoyed the experience.

As a person with Celiac's disease, I want to recommend Liliana's to anyone who is trying to avoid gluten. They are very accommodating, have a gluten-free menu, and can practically make anything on the regular menu gluten-free with some small modifications. Since being diagnosed, I have been inventorying the local Madison restaurants that i can count on for a good gluten-free meal, and Liliana's is definitely one of the best. An added plus is their rather prolific wine list and the nice atmosphere. Thanks for giving the gluten-deprived a great place to dine!!
Always great food and good wine. I am gluten free and the staff is well informed on the menu items and how to Recommend gf items. Also a great wine list!
Had shrimp creole along with bananas foster with bread pudding!  Flavor and portions was what I expected. Ordered online and brought back to my riom, doesn't get much better then that.

Started off with a bang. The appetizers were awesome (steak bruschetta and loaded tater tots). The service for our large group was very slow.  Took an hour to get our entrees.  The entrees were just ok.  No one from our group raved about their meal.  Overall, disappointing.

After my first couple of visits, I wasn't a big fan simply because I don't like the peppers or jalapeños that are in a large number of dishes here. That aside, the food is very good 

I really enjoyed the chicken salad po boy and sweet potato chips. The salmon is to die for. My husband loves the jambalaya and gumbo.

Called for reservation after a Badger Game - only tables available were in the bar area, which turned out just fine for my wife and me.
Excellent food, excellent service.
Will definitely recommend.

We popped int o Lilis on a friday evening at 8 and were promptly seated, which was great.  I was very impressed by their "by the glass" wine selection.  Sometimes you want to have a couple different wines! 

I had the Diablo Chicken.  It was good but not great.  We were warned it was a little spicy. It wasn't spicy at all.  The chicken was a bit on the dry side. My girlfriend had the mushroom risotto which was bomb.  Our waiter recommended that we add shrimp to the dish, and we're glad we did!  The dish had great flavor and texture. I would definitely order it again.

First of all this place has a friendly bar and very good live music to listen to. The bad is that it's loud in the bar and hard to have a conversation without talking really loud. Still, it goes with the club type scene and is ok.The six of us had dinner in a room that was out of the noise so was much better. We had an excellent waiter who was attentive and helpful. Our meal started with very good corn bread and an equally good salad. The food was another thing. The two cajun dishes were spicy hot but just didn't have the oh wow factor. The two steaks were just ok, and were not not hot enough but that can happen anywhere. The beignets were really pathetic. Dry and covered with the usual powered sugar they really missed the mark. Lilana's has been here a long time and seems to please lots of customers but it is not our go to place. Except for the music it's just not on our list of places to go back to.

This review is solely based on the 2018 Mother's Day Brunch.

At Liliana's, you have to pre-pay for Mother's Day Brunch with a specific time and number of people. So we pre-paid for 4 people at 1:30pm. We arrived on time and expected to be seated per our reservation. But to our surprise, we were immediately asked to wait. They were still trying to seat people with 1pm reservations. The three hostesses were rude and unprofessional, insulting the Mother in our group about how busy they were and that "everyone" was having to wait. It might have been their way to "console" us, but it just came off rude, and it was some of the worst customer service we have ever received. We heard swearing from at least one of the hostesses in side conversation as well. At this point, due to pre-paying, we didn't have the option to find another restaurant. So finally, after 20 long minutes of waiting, we were seated. 

After being led to the dining room, we were dismayed to see at least 4-5 tables open. It took at least 10 minutes for a server to greet us. We found out that a server wasn't assigned to us. We were just lucky to have a proactive and kind server ask if we had been helped, and then helping us when we said no. We really appreciated his attention and service. 

We were by the buffet line, and it kept getting backed up due to a consistent shortage of plates. After waiting for new plates to come out, we finally got in line for some food about 45 minutes after our actual reservation. 

The food was the highlight of the entire day. A good variety of options from typical breakfast foods (scrambled eggs, potatoes, fruit, bacon and ham) to some southern dishes with a cajun twist (cajun mac n cheese, shrimp and grits, biscuits and gravy, jambalaya). The shrimp and grits and jambalaya were delicious. 

As the check came, there was a required 20% gratuity even though the service didn't justify it. All in all, it was a true disappointment. I would highly encourage people to avoid Mother's Day brunch at Liliana's in the future. 

It's hard to write this as we love the food. So I would recommend going during a slower service time and solely for the food. The food is what keeps us going back. Hats off to the Chefs at Liliana's.

Pros: 
- Our waitress was nice and attentive
- Fresh and moist cornbread
- Local ingredients and live music

Cons
- Drinks took an inordinately long time coming
- The food, while good, is overpriced

It's interesting and refreshing to have Southern flavors and dishes up in Wisconsin, but this restaurant - in my opinion - falls somewhere in between the categories of Southern homestyle cooking and upscale cuisine and doesn't quite hit its mark. 

The food definitely aims high and offers ambitiously creative dishes, but the jalapeno butter would have been better as a smoother, blended butter and the truffles in the bacon truffle mac and cheese were not really used to benefit or elevate the dish and rather seemed like a missed opportunity. 

The blackened catfish on cheddar grits, however, was fantastic. The spice blend on the catfish was perfect and all of the dish's flavors complemented each other well. 

Ultimately, this restaurant is just fine. It's just not for me.

Liliana's was great. We were able to score a patio table without a wait on a perfect Saturday evening (well, it was early evening to be honest-and shortly after we arrived the patio was packed!). Even though it's right on McKee, the surrounding trees kept things quiet and it feels a little secluded. Our server was friendly and prompt but did go a bit overkill on the upselling (I get it, I get it. I was a waitress in a former life but it was a bit much). Dinner came with complimentary cornbread served with jalapeño butter. The cornbread had a nice flavor but really would have shined if served warm.

We started with the oysters-they had one from the East coast and one from the West. Both were great and very fresh. My boyfriend ordered a cup of the gumbo but at the pushing, er, suggestion of our server, upgraded to the bowl. The bowl is HUGE and comes with a ton of Andouille sausage (per the server, the cup does not have any sausage). The bowl is easily more than enough for a meal in itself-easily the largest bowl serving I've ever seen-by a lot. The server did also sell it on the fact that it reheats well and that did turn out to be true.

I had Liliana's pasta which was good. The chicken on it just kinda missed the mark for me so if I ordered this again I'd probably ask for it without the chicken. The shrimp was cooked perfectly and the red pepper cream sauce wasn't too heavy. My bf had the blackened catfish which he enjoyed but said he probably wouldn't order it again. I thought the grits his fish came with were awesome.

Top everything off with some live jazz and it was a very nice evening.
Overpriced and lacks in creativity and flavor.  Is it bad, no.  Is it worth my hard earned money, no.  Is it authentic, no.  Will I go there again, no.

I've only been here once, but they had me at delicious and complementary corn bread and sweet butter. 

The Jambalaya is definitely the thing to order here - there are few things in life I regret  not having done, and not ordering this might be one of them.  Fortunately, my husband did order it and I got a chance to slowly devour the enormous shrimp, sausage, and seasoned rice in one bite before he took his plate back.

They make their own sweet potato chips as a side. 

Friendly wait staff, and it's a good place to take children.  We don't come to Fitchburg that often, but we might be back again for Liliana's.

I really wanted to like this place.  I'd heard and read mixed reviews and now I see why.  We ate here for their New Year's Eve 6 course menu... so they had 6 chances to recruit me as a new regular, but with each course we became more and more disappointed and annoyed.

My first impression was that the atmosphere was great; music was fun, people were friendly and overall it was really well designed.  Everything was fine to start, I wasn't a huge fan of the amuse bouche, but nothing to hold a grudge over.  What started the downward spiral was the waitress bringing our second course, literally right after bringing our first course.  I don't like when anyone at a restaurant of this caliber says "I don't want to rush you, but here's your next course."  Who wants to let their soup sit off to the side of the table while they eat the first course.  That was pretty much the way the following courses went, down to bringing our check WITH the dessert.  

I could go into lengthy detail about each course; including having to send back spare ribs (but the second one was really good) or the waitress and her lack of knowledge of the entire menu right down to telling us our dessert was peanut butter / chocolate when it was really peppermint / chocolate or that myself and others around us kept getting bumped into by waitstaff cause the seating was too close together ... but I'll save the time.

Ultimately, when I go out for a meal that's costing a table of two $200, I expect an experience.  Bringing clean silverware with each course isn't asking a lot.  Saying "Can you keep your fork for the next course, I know that's kinda weird" by our waitress is not what a meal at that price point should offer.  Kitchen paper towels on the counter of the bathroom is not the impression I wanted to leave with, but that's what I got.

Went on a double date, but the experience started days before we arrived. They have a great online reservation system, was very easy to find and request a reservation. One of the reasons we chose Liliana's is because they had a two-piece jazz band, and I thought that would be a nice addition to the ambiance.

Arrived and got seated immediately at a lovely four-top near the window. I don't drink alcohol but had the Bloody Mary virgin style, came with a nice collection of pickled things and slices of hard sausage. We ordered the deep-fried cheese curds and bacon-covered scallops. Both were delicious and I'd put these curds up to The Old Fashioned any day.

Before I went a friend warned me that the portions are large and that the "half" portion would be more than adequate for one person. GOOD ADVICE!

I ordered a half portion of gumbo, and my brother and sister-in-law got the full portion of the jambalaya. My husband got the dinner portion of the large scallops. We all enjoyed our entrees, but it really was the mac and cheese that topped the meal. We got one of the Wisconsin-shaped skillets of the most decadent mac and cheese I've ever had. Very glad we shared it, very rich but a nice compliment between bites of our main dishes.

The ambiance is delightful, tasteful with ample space that we weren't not sitting on top of other guests. The service was good too, attentive enough to get help when needed, but not hovering. 

Finally, I was pleasantly surprised by the prices. I found them totally reasonable. All in all, great experience.

How is there not a line out the door for this place?!?! The staff here is awesome and super friendly the music is on point just a guy and his guitar tonight lost in song and the food? Oh man! If you haven't been to this place yet you're missing out. I had the crab cake which was light and crispy with a delicious sriracha mayo followed by the best short rib Po'boy I have ever had in my life and the pecan pie was great too. Now I have to sleep into my food coma but I'm so happy I decided to come into this place and try the food. I'll definitely be back! Hopefully next time I can meet the chef!

Great cooking class at Lilianna's today with Chef Dave.  It started out with an in-depth talk about how to deconstruct a beef tenderloin and the differences between a steer and cow loin.  The science behind searing vs grilling. Then into the commercial kitchen where we all got a chance to actually see and work with a beef loin and each of us dissected a chicken.  Which is WAY more than just hacking it into pieces.  It was amazingly easy once Chef Dave explained the different parts and the knife techniques.

Great discussions searing vs grilling, and we grilled the chicken breasts along with a sample of the beef tenderloin.  We seared the thigh/legs and made Coq au vin.  Of course we had to roast the chicken backs and scraps for broth.  

The hardest part of course was eating all the wonderful food we made.  No recipe cards, but Chef Dave shows you techniques that can be used for many different dishes.  I would recommend this class for anyone who would like to learn to be a grill master/mistress!

Spot on every time - cooked to perfection and awesome (and innovative) flavors.

I absolutely love the Tuesday fixed menu.  3 courses, a new theme every week that each dish ties into (S'Mores, Beets, PG-13 (think Pork Butt), and only $25 or a little extra if you want to try the wine pairings that go with.  

The jambalaya is on the menu every day and is to die for - every time we think about going out for dinner that is what my boyfriend asks for.  

I just moved from Fitchburg to Verona, which means I'll be much farther away from Liliana's but I have a feeling I'll be making the trek.

It would be understandable if you were to drive past this restaurant, as the exterior is as unassuming as a suburban urology practice.  However, unlike a trip to the urologist, coming here is a lot of fun.  In my opinion, the food is B-plus level, but it earns 4 stars for ambiance and service.  My wife and I enjoyed the classic Cajun dishes we ordered, etuffe and jambalaya.  The dining area is classy without being stuffy, and the jazz band was good, yet quiet enough for conversation.  This is an extremely versatile restaurant;  it is appropriate for a first date, a dinner with your spouse or entire family, or taking one's Mother out for her birthday.  Clearly, contemporary Wisconsin offers more than just cheese curds, and establishments like this one go a long way towards proving that.
The cornbread was delicious, and I loved the jalapeño butter it was served with. The service was quick, and it would be a wonderful place for a first date.

We went to Liliana's for a pre-movie dinner on a Saturday night and was delighted by our meal.  The menu has a pretty broad selection of Cajun and Creole dishes, muffaletta, and then some not-at-all Louisiana Bayou dishes.  The best part is that there's an entire vegetarian menu!  I had the vegetarian jambalaya, which had seitan instead of andouille.  The texture of the seitan was a little bit unexpected, but the entire dish was delicious.  My dining companion had the etouffee and thoroughly enjoyed it.  

The service was great.  Everyone was friendly and attentive. They were very generous with the cornbread and honey-jalapeno butter.  Yum!  

The restaurant is cute, with some metal work and crystal chandeliers, but it;s in a kind of odd location. Perhaps that's why it was pretty quiet, but this was honestly perfect for dinner before a movie just down the road at the AMC Fitchburg.

Also, dishes come in half and full size portions.  We got the half sized, which is just about right for a meal...but I kind of wish I had gotten the full, so I'd have leftovers.  It could be fun to get two half-orders though.  They had a tofu and grits dish that I was eyeing...

Went there on a Friday night with some friends.  The food was really good, a bit expensive for the amount, but hey it was worth it. The service was good and the food was too. There was a band playing and it got too loud to talk, but other than that it was a pleasant evening. I'll be back
Great food and friendly atmosphere. Nice outdoor patio. Kid-friendly too!
Hands down the best Cajun food in the Midwest.  Gumbo, jambalaya, cornbread all excellent.

I have tried nearly every restaurant in the Madison area, and I can tell you that this is among the top restaurants to experience at some point. Despite its rather costly menu (expect ~$25 per person after tip), you will certainly want to come back. Their appetizer menu is interesting, diverse, and VERY freshly prepared. I recommend the fried alligator or fried cheese curds (best in the city) to start off. For the main dish, I recommend the salmon, although everything is good (I have tried the tilapia, jambolia, scampi, salmon, angus fillet, and catfish). They have a very impressive wine menu, which pairs well with their servers' comprehensive understanding of wine. Try to come in at a time when a band is playing. Service is a definite 10/10. No need to make reservations. There is Literally no possible way to complain about this place.

Food is great, ambiance nice.  However the staff has a discriminatory leaning, as it took forever to get served when I was at the bar with a woman of color while they fawned over the other patrons. Will not go there again.

Decent Cajun food.  However I would say the price for what you get is not necessarily worth it.  We waited a long while for our food and it wasn't even super busy.  The environment is good and the ambience is great, however for what it's worth, New Orleans Take Out or the old Bayou downtown has quicker service and in my opinion better tasting food. All in all, would return but wouldn't be first choice.
As usual the food is great the atmosphere is warm and friendly. The wait staff helpful and attentive. I celebrated my birthday with begnets. Thanks Chef Heide!!!

Excellent food and atmosphere!  One of our go-to date night locations.  New to the menu will be a lobster mac-and-cheese which was fantastic.  My favorite meal, their jambalaya, will stay on the menu and is a go to favorite for me.  Cheese curds are some of the best in Madison.  All around great place.  All the food is great there.

Lordy! N'awlins in WI. Lunch special cup of soup or gumbo with half sandwich or half salad ( doesn't sound like much but half is a LOT) plus a plate of sweet cornbread w/lucious butter for $10. They just don't offer sweet tea. Great service, wonderful food, jazz in background, lovely photos throughout. Deserving of all the "Best of..." awards for 2017! Wish this place was in Knoxville.

We went to Liliana's for lunch and were impressed with the nice staff and good food.  It was a little crowded but my food (catfish po' boy) arrived pretty fast and was delicious. Really good french press coffee with free refills was a plus.  Seems like the patio would be great if it had been a bit warmer. I'll definitely go back.

Madison summer restaurant week 2017 experience: 

Love the outdoor seating with lovely flowers and guess what, they grow tomatoes here too! Amazing customer service. Our waiter was very friendly and funny. Huge portion. 

I chose the French quarter menu which was $35, one of the higher priced menu of restaurant week. 

Appetizer - Smoked salmon and fennel with herbed Montrachet crepe: I like the unique flavor of the herbed crepe but that was the only thing that stood out for me. 

Main course - Coq au vin with bacon and hidden valley mushroom with potato puree: When I said huge portion, I really meant it. Two people can finish this dish! The pork was very soft and moist but it was a bit salty for me. I like the flavor of the sauce but it wasn't very special. 

Dessert - Praline cream cheese torte with wild berry compote: Nothing above ordinary to be honest. The dish has a fancy display but its taste was just okay

So I had high expectations coming here, excited to try some southern food in Wisconsin! Well, being from South Carolina I can tell you this is absolute shit compared to what you get in Charleston! 

I ordered the blackened chicken creole. The chicken tasted that of Tyson's pre cooked chicken strips that you'd buy at Walmart. Not blackened whatsoever. Ordered on top of some canned red tomato sauce and cooked rice. $18. 

I dipped the chicken in the red paste and tried to make haste of what I had but alas it was terrible. The waitress noticed and discounted me the price of the disliked dish. My friend order the diablo chicken and complained about the chicken being "too rubbery."

We also ordered the buttery martini, which was yummy and the sangria. Drinks were good but food was under par for sure!! Do not recommend. I'd rather eat at Olive Garden or Carrabbas any day than here

Great food, great appetizers and great atmosphere. Every time I've come here I've enjoyed the food and the service has been wonderful. I love the vegetarian options. And the quality of food is off the charts!. Amazing cheese curds and delicious smoked tofu muffuletta!  Highly recommend!  (Mother's day brunch was awesome as well)
Had the $10 lunch special...oyster po'boy, came with salad or soup, sweet potato chips, white beans, homemade cornbread,  and a fresh lemonade. One of the best Cajun restaurants around.
The beignets were disappointing. The entrees were amazing, though, and the cornbread to die for!

Not sure why there are all the haters. This place always amazes.  The chef is a great guy and the food is incredible.  We had our wedding here and just continue to return for the food and ambiance.  One of the best kept secrets in the Madison area.  If you haven't tried it, you should.  They offer an impressive wine list and will do any wine by the glass.  We get great service and food every time we come here.  The Lilliana's burger will stand tall against any gourmet burger, the smoked wings amazing and if you like spicy the Chicken Diablo........ One word...... Sriracha!

My first time here and I was AMAZED. I have never left a restaurant feeling so satisfied. I had the Jambalaya and it was perfect; hot and delicious. I ended the meal with the chocolate mousse, which was also amazing. My boyfriend and I racked up quite a hefty bill, but it was worth every penny. We will definitely be back!

Nice motif and expansive menu.  This was my 4th visit and both the scallops and blackened catfish we had were dynamite.  Chef David does a fine job and is gaining a reputation in Madison.  A little pricey but worth a try.

I urge u even if u r not vegan, 2 cast ur conscience aside and lie and then beg them 2 make u the coconut peanut butter French toast with the rum brown sugar reduction.  Trust me on this.  Chef Dave premiered it 4 our brunch group yesterday and it was nothing short of orgasmic.  
Don't let the idea of it being vegan sway u ~unless u r vegan....then do!

This review is specifically for the Cajun Cooking class I attended on February 28th with Chef Dave. Having never paid money for a cooking class, I was excited to receive this as a gift.

The classes are capped at ~10 people, and are held when the restaurant is closed between brunch and dinner service on Sundays. Chef Dave noted that future classes will be held at their new restaurant, Charlie's on Main in Oregon.

The Cajun Cooking class began around the bar area with Chef Dave and his daughter Lily. Chef Dave provided some base knowledge for Cajun/Creole cuisine, dispelled some myths, and explained the agenda for the class.

Once in the kitchen, Chef Dave demonstrated the various types of roux that recipes may call for. I'm typically scared off my any recipe requiring roux, so this was really helpful to see and smell rouxs in various stages of cooking. Then we observed Chef Dave as he walked us through three popular Cajun dishes: gumbo, etoufee, and jambalaya. We tasted the sauces for these dishes along the way to learn how to bring them from good to great and enhance flavors. 

Lastly, we all sat down together to enjoy a meal. After a starter salad, we were brought out a plate with a serving of gumbo, etoufee, and jambalaya. Chef Dave was such a wonderful teacher all around, and his daughter made for some good comedic relief as well. This is a really great experience, and it makes a great gift for anyone that enjoys learning about food and home cooking!

Liliana's is so close by my house that I pass it up way too often and never think of stopping in.  That changed last night and I am so happy that I did.  It is a locally owned and committed to securing local ingredients wherever possible.  Dinner started out with a calamari appetizer as well as complimentary cornbread/jalepeno biscuits.  Both were outstanding.  The calamari was delicately fried and accompanied by a spicy aioli.  The bread was fresh and baked in house.  Both different types went well with the jalapeno compound butter that it was served with.  For our entrees, my girlfriend opted for the blacked cajun burger while I went with the jambalaya.  The burger was generous and perfectly blackened, coming out medium rare as requested.  The jambalaya was packed with shrimp, tasso ham, lardons, and chorizo.  Our server was attentive without being overbearing.  
Overall, we had a great experience and made me commit that I need to visit more often.  My only wish is that they had a few more sandwiches, etc. at a lower price point for the times I want to stop in for a quick bite rather than the entire dining experience.

Fantastic place with great service! Came here on a weekday evening with a group. Tried fried cheese curds. Tenderloin bruschetta, and crab cake appetizers. The tenderloin bruschetta was amazing; the beef was very tender. I am not a fan of blue cheese but it was well incorporated. Fried cheese curds were nothing short greasy and delicious. Crab cake was decent but I would personally skip it (can't comment too much on it because I recently lived in Baltimore, known for crab cakes). I ordered the scallops. They were nice and bitter and the mashed potatoes were well done. A very decent entree! Next time I would try the more authentic Cajun dishes though. For dessert I tried the beignets with chocolate mousse scooped over it. It was great. Bill came out to be a little pricey with everything but overall the food was fantastic!

Food was very tasty and the service was well done. Coraline was friendly and helpful. We brought our our own wine, and were charged a reasonable cork fee. The Cajun fare (gumbo, jambalaya) was spicy but very flavorful. Desserts were simple and balanced out the robust main courses. The only food I was not terribly impressed with was the hush puppies (a little bland) stuffed with Gouda and the etoufee (tasted like heavily spiced jerk seasoning).

We reserved a table online, which wasn't necessary on a Sunday but was nice that I could do it online.

I think a solid 3.5 stars would be more apt.  I went for lunch during restaurant week but decided to order straight from the regular lunch menu.  I ordered a Grilled Vegetable Po' boy (Foccacia with grill-roasted vegetables, greens, Red pepper aioli, and herbed Montrachet).  

It was ok.  Nothing surprising.  The portabello was a little on the burned side.  The sandwich was dripping wet to the point it made the bread soggy.  I abandoned the bread halfway through and ate the rest of the veggies with a fork.  The cheese was great, but when isn't goat cheese great?  They did not have an advertised beer available - not a big deal, but always kind of a bummer when you get excited to order something that is not available.

My server was nice enough in a fake way, but the interactions between the three staffed servers bordered on loud and inappropriate.  There were only two other couples in the restaurant on this Saturday afternoon yet we waited to have our orders taken for more than five minutes while listening to them talk about one girl's bad date from the night before.  I'm sure the whole restaurant appreciated the story.  Getting the check and a to-go box took about ten minutes - hard to rationalize that kind of service when there are 3 people working in an otherwise empty establishment.

It might be fun to go back during a dinner when the place is hopping and maybe the dinner menu is better?  They seem to have some glowing reviews otherwise.  3.5 stars for a passable if not forgettable lunch.

My friends and I went here for Sunday brunch and I loved it.  The decor is great, really very New Orleans like!  There was live music which was perfect, not too loud and annoying, just perfect with a guy playing guitar!  I had the sausage omelet which was perfect, I loved the chorizo, yummy yummy yummy!  My friends had the Jumbalaya omelets, I admit mine was better but it was still tastey!  The coffee was delicious!  Its hard to find a good rich coffee and this place was PERFECT!!!  I loved everything about this place!  The staff was great, attentive and friendly!

The crayfish etouffee is outstanding. The cornbread is nothing special. The lunch sandwich specials are a pretty good deal but frankly I'd rather go to Potbelly's. The atmosphere is cavernous and kind of weirds me out

I'll probably go there again since there isn't a whole lot of cajun food in this town but it's not my favorite spot
My husband and I love coming here! The food is always amazing. I've tried many of the dishes and have never left disappointed. The service is very friendly.

Went for lunch. The waiter took our order without writing it down, and the food took so long to arrive that when it came out wrong we didn't have the patience to send it back. I hereby resolve that the next time a waiter takes my order without writing it down, I'm walking out of the restaurant.

Wow, I absolutely love this place! I was visiting from Colorado and it's rare for me to have Cajun/Creole food so when the opportunity presents itself during my travels I take advantage of it.  This is now my new favorite Cajun restaurant.  The interior was beautiful, and the food was absolutely delicious. The leftovers were even amazing the next day!  I had the Jambalaya (best I've had) and Endive Salad (loved the truffle dressing).  I highly recommend a visit.

Ever wonder why Lilliana's is 1/2 full on a Friday night? Wonder no longer.

We had last been to Lilliana's several years ago. It was meh at best, and the reason we hadn't been back. Tonight we went at a friends choosing. We are no longer friends. I am sitting here formulating my revenge as we speak. Why would a friend do this to us?

We arrived at 8:00. Our friends were already seated. The waitress was pleasant. At least we had that going for us. It was all downhill from there.

We ordered and were surprised that the waitress tried to shill us a romaine salad. Ummmmm There has been an alert out on Romaine lettuce for the last three days. The CDC announced that NO romaine should be consumed. Seems like a restaurant should know this, no?I mentioned it to her and received a solid shrug. 

Several of us ordered an "endive" salad. The salad came and was cheap greens with 4 small slivers of endive. Niiiiice.

Gather around friends while I tell you about the cheese board. It's a tale fraught with perils and adventure. 3 pieces of cheese. One that we guessed was Velveeta's new white and spicy "cheese" product. Also on the plate were two dry triangles. Toast points? Oh no. Here's where it gets scary. We all tried this substance and one bite was enough. We assumed after trying this soylent green-styled cake that it was chorizo and summer sausage thrown into a food processor and then formed into a brick, then deftly sliced into delightfully dry triangles. Also on the plat was an unrecognizable pile of slop. A couple of us kept pointing at it asking what it was. The owner of the cheese board was confused. I finally took a bite knowing full well what I was getting into. Why would I do that? It turned out it was rice and chorizo that was overly seasoned with cumin or file'. We asked our waitress and she said it was "ko-ree-so." Good god...

My entree was the seared scallops. 4 quarter sized scallops sitting atop creamed corn, sitting atop 3 boiled and flattened potatoes. Served at room temperature. $21.

Beignets... Why one of our party ordered these after all that, I'll never know. Sigh... "Beignets." These were obviously made with mass-produced dough. Cisco? Pillsbury? For shame... 

All of this took 2.5 hours and it took 15-20 minutes to get any drink. Every. Time. Remember the restaurant was half full.

The final insult after terribly slow service and horrendous food? A 20% mandatory gratuity for a table of 6. You bastards. 

There was a reason we took years to come back. There's many reasons we'll never come back. Ever.

We went to Liliana's last night for their raw bar night for the bridal party's girl night out and the staff and food were incredible.  They made for a memorable night and even though the restaurant was busier than normal, our waitress and the bartenders went above and beyond to make us feel at home that we never felt forgotten.  The head chef/owner Dave even came out to our table to greet us warmly and when our dinner took took longer than normal to come out, our entire table was treated with champagne and drinks.  The food was certainly worth the wait and is most definitely the best seafood in the Madison area.  I recommend Liliana's Restaurant not just for the food but also for the most welcoming service you'll experience not just in Fitchburg, but in the entire Madison area.

OH MY. OH MY! 

I couldn't wait to write this review. I just booked two return visits and both will take place in July when my family visits, but I went last night for a group meeting and 
5 stars for the grilled chicken wings & Mussels. 
4 stars on the cajun cheese curds ( i mean it's fried so it's good but the dip is BETTAH - no typo). lol  PLUS the Bruchetta. 
2 stars for the crap service. 
4 stars for the server's assistance, hostess and bar tender
4 stars for Liliana's growing their own herbs in the garden next to the outdoor patio. I know y'all think this is Madison-chic but IT'S SOOOO NEW ORLEANS AUTHENTIC. When I saw the sous-chef pull around to get something with his kitchen dirty pants...I wanted to be bothered but it warmed my heart so that I reminisced about getting home sooner than 2013. 

I hate patio dining because of bugs and heat. YEP! I'm allergic to the heat (no joke) and I'm from the place of heat. Of course, the bugs were fighting for a place near the dishes. We ordered Mussels, 2-order of Wings, Cajun Cheese Curds, The Veggie trays ( I don't recall but one had pita bread..I think it was their take on cruidte), the BRUCHETTA was lovely and I can't stand tomatoes. It has a pesto base. We also ordered BBQ Shrimp. It's not BBQ Sauce but Creole style with butter and a bunch of spices. 

This place knows to stick to the recipes and butter so it can't be wrong. But I'm trying to live a long, healthy life so I wish they'd lay off some of the butter and find alternatives but then it wouldn't be NOLA food. But honey....let me tell you.... those Grilled Wings got my faithfulness. You know how many times I have to eat 1 wing and call it a day or skip them altogether because they're fried?!?! 

The kid gave a thumbs up to the Kid steak. Said it was flavored well and decent texture. Yep, kid CRITICs do exist. The kid didn't care for the mashed potatoes and protested how did "vegetables" on the menu turn into just 3 asparaguses. lol. I told the kid - "JUST EAT IT" 

I'm choosing to bypass the discussion regarding bad service, but the food is well worth the trip. I look forward to finally getting some beignets one day and not from the Bayou (On Butler). 

4.5 stars for the Ambiance because the MUSIC and setup tries to replicate any street in the Quarters or Uptown. But it's more Claiborne versus Tchoupitoulas. The Courtyard isn't New Orleans-eque because it's Fitchburg..there's only so much he can do but I respect and appreciate the effort. 

Oh by the way..... a barback ran out to the Herb garden and pulled what I assumed was some mint. Man!!! you got's to love hard work and effort. To that end, I pray and hope my next two visits exceed my expectations or at least just come out the closet and say, "EXPECT GOOD FOOD BUT SURLY SERVICE." That's okay. I've patronized and known a few establishments that lasted for generations under that mantra. Sad but true.

Though I have been to Liliana's a couple of times now, I still don't feel that I have actually experienced what Liliana's has to offer so I am definitely looking forward to going back and updating my review.

On my first visit, I was there as a vegan, yeah you read that right.  I went vegan for about a month or so and had the pleasure of trying dishes that I would not normally not try. On this particular visit, I have to say that I was disappointed by their lack of vegan friendly options.  After scanning the menu for a bit however, I was able to find the tofu wings.  Generally, not a big fan of tofu but def a huge fan of wings so I was interested in how it would be prepared.  The presentation was sort of lacking but I don't really know what I was expecting.  On my plate came about 6 strips of tofu in buffalo sauce.  It wasn't until after I received my dish that I decided to tell the waitress that I was vegan; at that she noted that the 'wings' had actually been fried in butter.  I didn't want to make a fuss and actually offered to keep it but she was so nice and insisted that they make me another plate, this time without the butter.  I was really impressed by how helpful she was.  

When I received my new plate, I ate the food and again, I don't really know what I was expecting but they were just okay.  Because they were advertised as wings, I was expecting a bit more texture but instead the tofu was pretty soft.   The buffalo sauce was good I guess :)  The meal wasn't all bad, the salad that I had to start was good and the date loved the etouffe that he ordered.  The table also came with cornbread which I was told was really soft and had a a great taste.

My second visit was on Valentine's Day.  This visit was also not a typical experience because there was a pre-set menu and unfortunately, none of the offerings were creole.  With that said however, I really enjoyed the meal.  There were five courses, all the same save the choice in entree.  It started out with a butternut squash soup, then salad, ravioli, and ended with a petite sirloin and chocolate mouse with strawberry.  Everything was delicious!  I really really enjoyed everything I ate and do not have a complaint.  The atmosphere was great and the service was outstanding.

I am really looking forward to trying this place under 'normal' circumstances and look forward to trying what looks to be a very interesting menu!

We went here for a cooking class and, although the chef had good intentions, we didn't learn much at all. He showed us how to sauteed onions and frost a kings cake. After we were served "the food we made" and it didn't seem like more than rice topped with tomato sauce. We have been back twice since to try other things on the menu, but still unimpressed.

My group got there at 7 on a Wednesday and thought we'd be able to get a table since there were some open in the dining room but we had to wait for a bit. While we waited we ordered drinks at the bar where it took about 5-10 minutes to get 2 waters and a drink from their menu. When we got to our table it took quite a long time for the waiter to take our drink and appetizer order, but that could have been because we were waiting for another person to arrive. Overall, we spent 2 hours there, which is quite long for a meal. When the check came, the waiter had put our appetizer on the one person's check who hadn't eaten any of it (he didn't even ask, he just joked that he was making her pay for it because she was late).

The food was delicious, but since then, 2 people have told me they've been sick from going there so I will probably not be going back.

Highlight/lowlights

1) gluten free options available 
2) slow service
3) good Cajun food

I had been to Lilliana's before, and remembered having a good experience. We had a city tin (Lilliana's is included in the 2015 pack!) so we decided to come back. We came on a Saturday night with no reservation and we were seated right away. We didn't have to wait last time either so I would say reservations are more of a nice to have than a need to have here. 

Outdoor seating is available and the space is a cute patio. Only negative here is your view is of Fish Hatchery Road, but overall still a nice outdoor seating space. 

The menu is pretty big with a large variety of southern style cocktails, appetizers and Cajun entrees. Menu options that are gluten free are labeled, but they also label options that can be modified to be gluten free which is really great. I tried the southern sangria which was very bourbon-y but good! You get corn bread with Cajun butter complimentary with your meal- sadly not g free but supposedly really good. We also had the Wisconsin cheese "taste" which was only $5 and perfect for two! Our entrees were pretty good, I had the Creole chicken and he had the gumbo. 

Our one major disappointment at Lilliana's was how slow the service was. There were tables open inside and out and it didn't seem that busy, but the service was slow. We were there for almost two hours and we just had one app, our entrees and one drink each. Not sure if since it was later they had already sent some of their wait staff home or what but we were really disappointed with the service.

Overall, good Cajun food, nice ambience but be prepared to wait!

The first time I was here, I got scallops. They smelled and tasted very strongly of ammonia, which is produced as they rot. Either they didn't taste, smell, examine the scallops for freshness, or they did and sent it out anyway. Not sure which is worse. Ordinarily, I would have given one star and never gone back. In their defense, I was part of a party of 20+ people, which I imagine is pretty hard to deal with in a small-ish restaurant.

However!

They have one of the most vegetarian-friendly menus in the Madison area. We gave them another try on a vegetarian night. We found the vegetarian options to be plentiful, well-seasoned, well-flavored. Dude knows how to cook!

Prices and service, are good. Ambiance is fantastic.

Bring your veggie friends there, especially when you're wanting something a little different from the token black bean burger every other menu has got.

Maybe the scallops were a rare accident, but the memory of the smell is powerful and I don't think I can eat seafood there again.

Impressive wine selection,as noted by Wine Spectator. Best cornbread I've ever tasted. Brunch is stellar with housemade beignets and bottomless mimosas. They make some rather tasty oysters Rockefeller. Service has been hit or miss, but I've had some very memorable evenings given the romantic decor. They often have live music, which helps reinforce the New Orleans vibe. You could bring your kids (especially enjoying the outdoor patio), but there is a general upscale vibe to the place.

I adore Liliana's. The food is always excellent, they focus on using local ingredients, and the bar tending staff always has wonderful suggestions.

If you're pressed for time at lunch, I wouldn't recommend them, as it's hard to get in and out in an hour.

They also offer a Tuesday night themed tasting menu each week, which is always fun, a Thursday night wine night with two wine tastes and two tapas, and many special events, as well as cooking classes.

One of my favorite spots in town.

Liliana's is tucked away on the edge of Fitchburg and is completely unassuming from the outside. We stopped by for Restaurant Week PUMPDIZZLED to see a vegan menu. Not every day you see this, people! The menu included: salad of carrots, tomatoes, radish and caramelized onion vinaigrette, entrée of blackened seitan with sweet potato puree and julienned vegetables, and a gluten free/vegan chocolate cake. The salad was straight-forward, but I enjoyed the vinaigrette- tangy and not too sweet. The entrée was tasty with roasted red peppers and perfectly sautéed zucchini. I could eat that sweet potato puree for breakfast lunch and dinner, jus' sayin'. The cake, however, was totally dry and I only had a couple bites. I get that gluten free and vegan is a tough combo, but figure that ish out before putting it on the menu.

We sat outside and listened to some awesome live guitar and singing. I would go back just to sit out there on a summer night, sip a drink, and watch the sunset over the prairie! That's something you just don't get on the Isthmus.
Brunch shrimp and grits and bottomless mimosa's at lilianas
Fantastic. 2 adults, 3 kids, everyone loved it.

This place has really good food and really good atmosphere. For brunch, they said they could do most of the menu items dairy-free (not that I am, but I have a friend who is). The portion sizes are also pretty satisfying and I really fell in love with their crab cakes for some reason. I'm always excited and happy to eat here.

I can only rate this based on a single visit over lunch, but I'll definitely try to make it back for dinner (and more lunches!)  The complimentary cornbread was great (they're not afraid to load it with sugar!), and the lunch special sandwich w/ soup or salad is a relative bargain at $10 (or $11 if you swap out the standard soup for a cup of jambalaya like I did).  Shrimp Po'boy, sweet-potato chips, and a little bit of some sort of pasta salad-- Yum!  Service was great-- handled our large group great and even proactively offered separate checks which was nice.

We made a reservation for lunch since we'd heard that sometimes they fill up, but it was not crowded at all when we went on a Tuesday.

Looks like they're serious about accommodating gluten-free, vegan, or whatever other dietary restriction might be in style these days.
Good food, not as flexible on substations like making the crab cake an entree...which sounds simple. I can say I've experienced it and it was a nice nourishing meal.

Came for the first time tonight. Ordered the Jambalaya and the Gumbo. Both were really good with the Gumbo bring the favorite of the two. For dessert we had the beignets, 3 tasty treats for $4!!  I highly recommend it!!

I've been here a couple times, and every time I've been underwhelmed. Not that the food is bad, just that for the price and the atmosphere, I really expect more. I asked for recommendations from the waiter, and he recommended the three most expensive items on the menu. I ordered one, and my partner ordered another, and we were both disappointed with our food.

I am fed up with so many midwest restaurants calling themselves "Louisiana/New Orleans style" "Creole style" "Southern Style". It's no where near the real deal. It is a complete shame. 

I dined here a few months back on a Saturday evening. It was pretty late and the restaurant was about to close in a hour or so. This could have been my fault for coming later in the evening when the kitchen was so close to shutting down and not providing good food. Still, for a  $50 meal for two, I expect better. There was a live  jazz band playing. They were very good. It added some good ambience to the restaurant. Really enjoyed the music. Now on to the food

 My boyfriend and I were giving some cornbread with a honey butter as a starter from our waitress. I know corn bread and this is NOT cornbread. It tasted like Jiffy Mix batter and they added a bit more sugar. I've eaten all kinds of corn bread before, boxed cornbread, homemade cornbread even the class "hot water" cornbread, so I feel like I can safely say that I have a qualified taste pallet to rate  some good cornbread and this just isn't it.

The honey butter however was good. It would be proper to add it with a fresh loaf of warm bread. But I am of the belief that when you have a great piece of cornbread in front of you, you do not need to add more butter. The cornbread itself should have enough in it that all you want to do is indulge yourself into another piece. No add ons!

Moving on from the cornbread, I order this blackened cash fish dinner with dirty rice and side of I believe blackeye peas with various veggies in it including (collard) greens. My rice was very hard and my blackeye peas were cold. Again, maybe it was a mistake to dine there 1 hour before closing time. My rice tasted like it may had been scrapped from the bottom of the rice cooker and the dish ended up having pork in it which I do not eat. Knowing creole food, I should have asked the waitress beforehand if pork was used in the dish ,so that is of no fault of the restaurant, however, the hard rice and cold peas are. The catfish was blackended to perfection but it lacked flavor. No salt. A pinch would have done the trick. Overall, an extremely disappointing experience and is not in my opinion New Orleans style cuisine.

 If you were to take this restaurant and move it to New Orleans, they wouldn't survive. Due to their location, I think they stay open simply because they have no other local competition in the area of "creole" cuisine and some people aren't use to either cooking this kind of food themselves or actually experiencing  food straight from New Orleans. 

I really do not want to be the one review that seems to go overboard but I am very opinionated about this restaurant. I can cook better than what I was served. Sorry.

I've been a loyal Yelp user for a a couple of years but always hesitant to share my dining experiences with others.  After our dining "experience" tonight, the hesitation is over....

We had a Madison Originals gift certificate expiring, so rather than burning it, we decided that we would have a rare Sunday night out.  Their website indicated that Sunday was Family Night and kids ate free, so we were excited to check it out.  We got to the restaurant just before 6:00 and there were maybe 7 or 8 tables of diners.  We sat outside since the weather was nice.  Server was very friendly even though it was a bit odd that they didn't have any kid's menus given that it was "Family Night."  

Our server was at our table promptly and took our drink order.  When our drinks showed up, I asked if there were any options on the kid's menu other than what I could pull up on my Smartphone.  Before I could finish my question, he ran off and said he would get us a kid's menu... 20 minutes later we now had a new server and a kid's menu.  Not sure what happened to the original server but our kids thought it was odd that he disappeared.

I asked the new server what she recommended for entrees and she suggested the tilapia, ribs, and jambalaya.  I order the tilapia and my wife ordered the salmon.  Our son ordered the mac and cheese and our daughter the mushroom pasta.  10 minutes later, the server came back and said the mushroom pasta was gone, so she got the mac and cheese too.

Around 20 minutes later our drinks were long gone and the server brought out the kids meals and said ours were on the way.  Kids asked for some ketchup, which never did show up.....

While our meals were "on the way," the kids progressed to eat most of their food while we waited and waited.  Eventually our food showed up.  I thought mine was good.  My wife wasn't impressed with her salmon or risotto.  We ended up eating the rest of the kids mac and cheese and thought that was might tasty!

After about a half an hour the server finally checked on our table again.  We promptly asked for our bill.  When she brought it out, we paid without seeing the bill as the kids had to get to bed on a school night and we had already been there for 1.5 hours.  After a while, the wife and kids went to the car while I continued to wait.  The table next to us went inside to pay as they had waited long enough too.  After over 20 minutes, the server asked if I got my bill back.  I reminded her that she took it but never brought it back.  

Thankfully when the check and my credit card re-surfaced, it was actually processed correctly.  Had it been wrong, I'd probably still be sitting there....

While the food is alright, the service is horrendous.  Diner beware!

Excellent Cajun food, and one of my favorite local restaurants that always has MULTIPLE gluten-free options available, regardless of the time of day. They also focus on using locally-sourced, seasonal ingredients, which I appreciate.

The staff is pleasant, knowledgable, and always kind about answering questions, whether they're about the food, good wine/drink pairings for their menu options, or anything else!

They can get busy, so I'd recommend reservations during traditionally busy times, but even that's a simple process (you can call, or make them online!)

I would agree with the other reviewers...it kinda surprises you.
We went there on a lark....I had just defended my Ph.D dissertation and we wanted to go celebrate somewhere nice but still keep it casual (I was wearing checkered shorts!) Of course, I had read reviews on yelp earlier :-)

The ambiance is very romantic...especially when it's dark outside and the lights inside go on. The service was very attentive but not intrusive.
The wine we ordered for the table (recommended by the waiter) was very good...so was the cheese plate....which, btw, was plentiful...with crostini and 4 kinds of mustards...for $10???...hello, that's cheap!!...and how could i forget...the complimentary corn cakes were so good I asked for seconds :-)

I had the Creole trio....which allowed me to try their 3 main cajun/creole entrées...jambalaya, Étouffée, and gumbo. Now keep in mind that this was my first introduction to cajun/creole food.....i would say the food was good but not exquisite....all the 3 seemed to give me similar flavors...especially the gumbo and the Étouffée.....now that maybe how it's supposed to be...but since they were being served together, they should have been more "unique"....but nonetheless, it was yummy!

Take ur wife here on a romantic date and she won't be disappointed....also plenty of nice window seating and not very crowded....thats a plus...although a crowd does add to the "feel" of a place....but, i can't complain....we were there on a monday night at 8.30...so we missed the jazz pianist that people talk about i guess :-(

Tried Liliana's for the first time yesterday, since we've had a coupon on the fridge forever for free baguettes.

The decor inside was exceptional.  It was very New Orleansesque, complete with streetlamps and beads hanging overhead.  There's also some cool photography that the owners took themselves.

They start you out with cornbread, which by the way, was phenomenal.  Let it be known that I'm a sucker for good cornbread and haven't had it in awhile, so that alone made my visit.  I'd be happy to go back to this place for drinks and a bit of the spongy stuff.

For appetizers, went with calamari.  Not the best that I've had, as it was fairly tasteless. A spritz of lemon and lime helped out.  Neverless, we polished the plate off.

The one downside of the visit was the wait once our food was in (similar to other reviews).  I wouldn't have expected our order to take as long to bring out, as it ended up being roughly an hour or so between ordering and receiving our food. Minus 1 star.

The food made up for it though. The tilapia was done well, falling apart when I tried to pick it up.  No knives required!  As a bonus, it was on top of sweet potato mash, which competed for the top taste of the day.

There was also some outdoor seating, but considering it was rainy, windy, and 34 degrees...we passed.  Could be worthwhile when it's a bit balmier out.

Lilliana's in Fitchburg, WI
I should start this review with my bias. I am a huge foodie, food advocate, and eater! I get an amazing rush when I eat good food and I do believe you can get great food at Lilliana's! It's delicious and no on can take that away from them. 
Now, when I am reflecting on my most recent experience at Lilliana's, I know that there is no level of good food that could make me set foot into this restaurant again. Let me tell you what happened...
So my husband and I went out for brunch about 3 days ago. We decided to go to Lilliana's because when we were there for dinner Friday night, the waiter (who was great) talked up the brunch menu. So it is Sunday and we are seated against a window. There are several other guests, some eating and some not. It takes a bit meet our waitress which I now know was because she had gotten slammed with 5 tables all by herself at once. It wasn't a problem but by the time we got our food we knew something g had changed. I noticed she was attending to other tables multiple times without attending to us. I actually had to go fill up my water as a bus boy came by. I then had to go behind the bar to get more ketchup because NO ONE WAS HELPING US! I usually don't do this, but I got up for a third time to asked the waitress if she could help us. She told me she was letting us eat and did not mean anything by it, but when no one came again for us to pay for our meal, I knew this just wasn't right. I asked to speak with a manager because I was the only person of color there and I was the only person not being served--believe me, I looked. I had enough! The manager told me he would check the security tape and get back to me. He took my contact information and I left. 3 days later and I still am yet to hear from him. Whether it was racism or not, the behavior was unacceptable and the follow through was non-existent. I'm through!

Found this place on Yelp...in the area for a business trip.  Holy crap!  This place has some of the best Cajun food I've ever had.  I did a split entree of Jambalaya and Etouffee...both were amazing!  My boss had the Chicken Diablo and said it was "ridiculously good". We also split the cheese curds and cornbread...all 5 star goodness!  

No doubt when we travel back to this area, we WILL be going to Liliana's

Great location and decor! A group of friends and I went here on a Saturday afternoon around 1 PM for lunch (they only have brunch on Sundays, so be aware of that!), and we were not disappointed! 

Many of us got the Blackened Catfish Poboy, which was fantastic. I'm not even that big of a fan of creole/NOLA style food, but I really enjoyed the fish and the bread. The complimentary cornbread was also super appetizing! One of my friends enjoyed a gluten-free sandwich, commenting that it didn't fall apart as easily as most gluten-free sandwiches do, so I think this would be a great place to go if you need to eat gluten-free.

Overall, the service was surprisingly slow given that we were the only group there aside from another party of two. I've heard great things about this place for dinner, so I plan on coming back for that! I would definitely recommend this place if you've been wanting to try out NOLA-style food!

Why have I waited so long to come check this place out?! 
Food was very pretty & absolutely delicious. 
The service was great. Very friendly. 
Super excited to see multiple vegetarian options on the menu. 
Totally recommend.

Great place for food and drinks. Good atmosphere and it's a place that has something for everyone. I really like the smoked tofu wings (I don't think that these are on their official menu) and the crudites for snacking. These are two awesome apps to have along side a Pat O'Brien or a Liliana (two of their delicious cocktails). They do have a daily HH that offers both appetizer and drink specials. I think my next trip will include dessert first. I need to try their beignets. This place does come close to NOLA food. The touch of music in the background is really nice during the meal.

I've visited Liliana's twice in the past 6 months, once for lunch, once for a special occasion dinner.  While I did enjoy my lunch experience, the restaurant delivered a disappointing performance for my anniversary dinner where the lackluster food and service just did not jibe with the high price tag.

During my lunch foray, I ordered the fried shrimp po'boy, the tomato bisque, white bean salad, sweet potato chips and a slab or cornbread as part of the $10 lunch special.  Given that the po'boy normally goes for $13, the lunch special is a decent value if you come hungry.  Other than the pedestrian bread, I felt the sandwich was well prepared.  The well-seasoned fried shrimp, which came with a tempura-like coating, were a bit awkward to consume, given their gargantuan size.  For a restaurant serving Cajun-inspired cuisine, the spice level was quite mild.  The tomato bisque packed a surprisingly pleasant punch of tomato flavor.

Our amiable server made a conscious effort to engage with us and my dining companion and I enjoyed our banter with her.  The pace of the meal was very slow for a lunch service and we had to flag down our server a couple of times to see to find out the status of the next course.  The leisurely lunch works doesn't work too well during the work week if you need to squeeze a lunch into a 60 minute time slot.

My recent Friday night dinner experience did not go as well.  We didn't have reservations, so rather than wait an hour for a table in the dining room, we elected to eat on the patio.  No one wiped down the table after its previous patrons departed, so we did the best we could to clear the debris - not an auspicious way to start our meal.  

There was live entertainment in the bar and the patio speakers allowed us to enjoy the act (it was a bit loungey - think 'Girl from Ipanema' type of tunes, but the performers were talented, so it added an enjoyable backdrop to our meal).

Our server, who conveniently arrived after we wiped down our own table, tried hard, really too hard, to engage us by feigning a familiarity that did not exist. It made for an awkward experience throughout the meal.  My wife was put off by his efforts to help her navigate the wine list, which frustratingly did not list the country / region of origin.  After a couple minutes of spinning her wheels, she gave up and ordered a beer.  

One of the reason I decided on Liliana's was the cheese curds, but alas, no cheese curds for us, the restaurant was completely out.

We then decided on the cheese board ($17), which offered 6 Wisconsin cheeses, crostini, candied pecans fresh fruit and mustard.  When the board arrived, our server provided a cursory list of the cheeses, not indicating the provider or whether the cheese was cow, sheep or goat. (Other than the fact the cheddar came from Hook's).  The fresh fruit consisted of two semi-ripe strawberries and the candied pecan were nowhere to be found.  The pungent mustard was excellent, but the crostini was extremely dry and crumbled into pieces when we attempted to bite into it.  While the kitchen was generous with the portions, none of the cheeses where memorable other than the cheddar and the Gouda.  When I asked about the candied pecans, our server kind of blew me off, saying that the kitchen must have forgot to place them on the board.  I understand the kitchen may run out of ingredients, but it would be nice if the server would mention that when delivering the dish and asking if something else could be substituted in its place.

The next small plate we sampled was the brie bruschetta.  While I enjoyed how the jammy goodness of the fig & pear compote paired with the creamy brie, my dining companions did not share my enthusiasm.  My biggest complaint is the lackluster bread.  While it had a couple of grill marks for texture, it needed more toasting to handle all the moisture from compote, and became a soggy mess soon after it was delivered.  And in a town with so many fantastic bakeries, I was disappointed in the spongey, bland bread that lacked any substance. 
My daughter order ended up ordering the Wisconsin mac & cheese, served up in a cast iron pan in the shape of Wisconsin.  While impressed with the ingredient list, I expected a creamer rendition of this classic.  Sadly, a puddle of watery cheese sauce prevented the cast iron from caramelizing the ingredients on the bottom of the dish.  I really expected more richness from this meal, which was overpriced at $17.

I expect I will not return to Liliana's for dinner, as there are so many better local option in this price point (Brasserie V, Sardine, Heritage Tavern to name a few) that offer more consistent execution of their food and service. However, given the proximity to Liliana's to my workplace, I do expect to return for an occasional lunch when my schedule gives me enough flexibility for an extended break.
Great cheese curds! The service was great. Lots of vegetarian options! It was a tad spicy for my taste but that's because I'm a wimp. But I would go back.

Finally, a place with unhealthy vegetarian food! I am so there! I went for lunch and got the tofu wings appetizer. The batter is very light, almost tempura style and the tofu has a nice smoked flavor to it. The dish came with a hot sauce and bleu cheese dipping sauces allowing for the diner to decide how much heat they would like with each bite. These are the best tofu wings I have had in the Madison area and they are very hard to find in the Midwest in general! However, I still think the price point is a little steep, but apparently they are 1/2 off during happy hour - this I will most definitely be exploring! The dish also was served with celery and carrots. 

For the main I chose the fried shrimp po'boy. The shrimp were large and had the same light batter as the wings. The bread was really spot on with the crunchy exterior and solid sourdough flavor.
